postcontent: This is a very good condition Mass. Arms .31 Maynard primer revolver. It is one of one thousand produced with serial number 598. The primer door is marked "Maynard's Patent/Sep. 22,1845" and the top strap is marked "Mass. Arms Co./ Chikopee Falls." The function is fine and the hand turn cylinder (to beat Colt's self revolving cylinder patent) Is good. Door opens smoothly and the accessories are lovely. The Flask is very good with the Mass. The cartridge packets are repros of an original made expressly for Mass Arms, very cool and there are even a few rolls of original Maynard primers in there. The case is very nice walnut but not of the period. Now the good part. I believe this one to be one of a 200 gun shipment to Ron Brown before the Civil War. I have researched this gun for a short time (one pot of coffee on a Minnesota winter Sunday afternoon) and found on the internet a letter (copy included)from Geo. L. Stearns to Brown offering to act as an agent in procuring the 200 pistols and confirming a price of $6.50 each, another letter (copy included) from John Brown to his supporter W.H.D. Collender, telling Collender how he intends to pay for the order and adding "I am on my way west." There is a copy of the letter from Stearns (see above) to the Mass. Arms Co. finally ordering the 200 pistols at $6.50 each to include powder flasks, bullet molds and extra mainsprings, such order to be forwarded to John Brown in Iowa City, Iowa by mail! I bought this gun at a gun show ten years ago that is on the Iowa Nebraska Minnesota border so it comes from the neighborhood of the 1856 shipment, or maybe later from Kansas just one state away. I have other letters and info that comes with this one and you will find several leads stamped on the letter copies from the museums. Please understand that I do not have a serial number match or anything that proves John Brown bought this but after looking through the minutes of his groups meetings (all on file at the University of VA and Kansas State Historical Society) and finding it so near to where he raised hell you can probably prove it as there are documents everywhere on the internet but it will take some research. title: For Sale:  Colt 1861 Navy .36 Cal. - 4 Digit # - Unusual Grip
postcontent: This is the much rarer Model 1861 Colt Navy revolver. Made in a smaller size for the Navy, with the caliber reduced to .36". The Colt Model 1861 Navy cap & ball .36-caliber revolver was a six-shot, single-action percussion weapon produced by Colt's Manufacturing Company from 1861 until 1873. It incorporated the "creeping" or ratchet loading lever and round barrel of the .44-caliber Army Model of 1860 but had a barrel one half inch shorter, at 7.5 inches. Total production was 38,000 revolvers. This Colt has a four digit serial number 22XX, and was produced very close to the start of the production run of 1861 or 1862. The serial number is on the frame, trigger guard, cylinder and even the wedge.The cylinder has some of the original battle scene still evident. Usually the scroll is completely gone, especially for such an early piece. Pretty nice.The action is rather good, and the cylinder does a complete turn when the hammer is retracted. The hammer locks into position, and fires as it should. The original trigger was missing when I got it, so I had a gunsmith put in a reproduction. He even case hardened it just like the originals were made! If I didn't tell you, you wouldn't have known...The barrel still retains the Colt name and address. The bore is rather nice with solid lands and grooves. There is some slight brown surface oxidation marks, but really on the light side. Overall it has a nice gray appearance, with some minimal blue under the loading lever.The loading lever is nice, and retains some light blue. It operates nice and tight, and the plunger inserts into the cylinder properly.The wedge is original, and has the same serial number 2XX. The spring is a replacement, and needs the screw to hold it in place. The side screw for the wedge is missing, and a replacement is needed.The most unusual and intriguing characteristic of this revolver is the handles. When I first looked at it we thought it was from a Remington. Or maybe from a Confederate revolver. Or maybe Manhattan? We matched them up to every revolver we knew of, and it did not match any of them. I took them off and they are a perfect set of production brass castings, not something a blacksmith or gunsmith made. They match up to all of the surfaces and screws perfectly. It is like they were an aftermarket or Colt experimental set of grips and frame. The wood had a small sliver out of them, which the gunsmith fixed. They are very intriguing, and are certainly 100+ years old. Patina and wear matches all the way around. If someone wanted to fake them, they would have just used a current repro set... The grips are secured to the brass frame with a Remington style center pin. See the pictures for details. If you have any information on this alteration, please let me know!With this low serial number, this revolver certainly saw its fair share of action during the Civil War. Really a neat revolver, with an interesting grip variance.

postcontent: This is an original, very fine condition Civil War Burnside Cavalry Carbine that appears to be unissued.The Burnside Cavalry Carbine was one of the most popular carbines during the war on the Union side. Only the Sharps and multi-shot Spencer Cavalry Carbines were issued in larger numbers. The Burnside Carbine was invented by Ambrose E. Burnside, who was the Treasurer of the Bristol Firearms Company before the Civil War. Burnside's pre-war financial difficulties caused him to sell his interest in the company in June 1859.Eventually the Bristol Firearms Company became the Burnside Rifle Company but Burnside had no financial interest in, or control over, this company when the Civil War began. As a result, Burnside never personally profited from the large number of weapons purchased during the war. Burnside did, however, see to that cavalry units under his command were armed with carbines of his design during the war. Ambrose Burnside became a major general during the Civil War and was the ineffectual commander of the Union Army of the Potomac at Fredericksburg before being demoted to commander of the Union IX Corps, which he led for the remainder of the war without distinction.The Burnside Carbine underwent several design modifications during its production life. The First Model, which was made by the Bristol Firearms Company in Bristol, Rhode Island, was a .54 caliber percussion, breech loading carbine with a tap primer system that was integrated into the frame. The First Model did not have a forend stock and only about 300 were manufactured before the Civil War began. The Second Model Burnside was also made by the Bristol Firearms Company and is principally different than the First Model by the elimination of the tape primer system and incorporation of the traditional cap primer system. Approximately 2,000 Second Models were produced from 1860-1862.The Third Model was manufactured by the Bristol Firearms Company and differs from the Second Model by the addition of a wooden forend and a different style hammer. Approximately 1,500 Third Model Carbines were manufactured, all in 1862.The introduction of a new hinged breech action, which prevented the breech block from falling too low beneath the frame during reloading (it sometimes traveled so low that it became disengaged from the frame entirely), created the Fourth Model. There has been much confusion about the Fourth Model Burnside Carbine with some sources in recent years stating that the Fourth Model should be broken down into a Fourth and Fifth Model. The Fourth Model had a double-jointed breech action and hinge bolt making it easier for troopers to load and extract cartridges. The final or "Fifth Model," was made by adding a screw-pin in the right side of the frame to improve the functioning of the carbine. The Ordnance Department during the Civil War referred to the Fourth and "Fifth" Models as the Model 1863 Burnside Carbine and would purchase over 50,000 by war's end. Adding more confusion to the proper nomenclature of Fourth/Fifth Model 1863 Burnside Carbines is the fact that the production run from 1863 to 1865, approximately 43,000 carbines, are all marked on the receiver “MODEL OF 1864.”This Model 1863 Burnside Carbine is serial number 27384, and is in NRA Antique Very Fine Condition.
